awd_titl_txt: TWC: Frontier: Collaborative: CORE: Center for Encrypted Functionalities
awd_abstract_narration:
The Center for Encrypted Functionalities (CORE) tackles the deep and far-reaching problem of general-purpose "program obfuscation," which aims to enhance cybersecurity by making an arbitrary computer program unintelligible while preserving its functionality. This can in turn enable a host of applications, such as hiding from potential adversaries the existence of vulnerabilities that may have been introduced through human error in the design/development process, thereby preventing tampering or deterring reverse engineering, or hiding cryptographic keys within software, thereby strengthening encryption and information transfer. 
 
At the heart of the Center's research activities is the development of new and rigorous mathematical techniques to build faster and more secure general-purpose mechanisms enabling such software. In pursuit of this goal, the CORE team tackles many technical questions: Can secure general-purpose mechanisms avoid the inefficiency overhead that arises from Barrington's Theorem? Can the security of these mechanisms be proven to hold against idealized adversaries, or be based on natural non-interactive hardness assumptions? Can these approaches be securely leveraged to protect data from rogue insiders, who must be able to access some data in the clear? Finally, can these mechanisms be used to reduce the level of interaction required to accomplish secure communication and computation tasks? In addition to its direct research program, the Center organizes retreats and workshops to bring together researchers to carry out the Center's mission. The Center also engages in high-impact outreach efforts, such as the development of free Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs).

por.por_cntn:
The inherent tension between securing data and using it effectively has motivated many decades of research in cryptography and cybersecurity - constantly pushing researchers to discover new tradeoffs and tools for drawing finer and finer distinctions between desired and legitmate data uses and illegitimate ones. This same challenge is only beginning to be explored for code - where the two goals of secrecy and usability are even more directly in conflict. How does one distribute working code while still protecting its secrets? This is a question that is core to issues of intellectual property as well as safety: how might one, for instance, distribute a patch for a software vulnerability without the patch itself helping malicious parties to discover and exploit that vulnerability in the machines that are not yet patched? 

It has long been a dream of cryptographers to approach these kind of questions with the same level of mathematical rigor that has been achieved in data encryption. However, it has only recently begun to seem possible. Our research as part of the Center for Encrypted Functionalities pushed the boundaries of knowledge in this area of cryptography, tackling the task of encrypting code while retaining its usability. We greatly advanced the state of the art in techniques for reasoning systematically about the security of these kinds of cryptographic systems. One cornerstone of our work was a paper entitled "Indistinguishability Obfuscation from the Multilinear Subgroup Elimination Assumption, appearing in FOCS 2015. We then further advanced our techniques to apply to Turing machines, a very robust model of computation, in a follow up paper appearing in STOC 2015. 

Many students and young researchers contributed to this research effort, and became experts in cutting-edge cryptographic techniques as a result. This included phd students, undergraduate student researchers, and a postdoc who was supported on the project. Results were disseminated to the wider research community through conference publications and invited talks.
